title: 106_s1524
content: The Act is titled the "Motor Carrier Safety Specialist Certification Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century aims to improve motor carrier, commercial motor vehicle, and driver safety through strategic safety investments and identifying high-risk carriers and drivers. The Act also supports safe transportation of passengers and hazardous materials to reduce commercial motor vehicle crashes. The General Report on the Federal Highway Administration's Motor Carrier Safety Program highlighted issues with enforcing safety regulations and targeting high-risk carriers. The Safety Status Measurement System (SafeStat) was found to have incomplete and inaccurate data, limiting its ability to identify carriers with the worst safety records. Testimony also revealed limitations in targeting high-risk carriers due to outdated census data. The Act aims to establish a certification program for Motor Carrier Safety Specialists and set standards for carrier compliance reviews. It also addresses the lack of protocols for accepting safety data from third-party specialists to promote highway safety. The Act establishes a certification program for Motor Carrier Safety Specialists to set standards for carrier compliance reviews and improve highway safety. The Act establishes a program for training and certifying motor carrier safety specialists by an organization designated by the Secretary of Transportation. The Motor Carrier Safety Specialist Certification Act requires safety compliance reviews to be conducted by certified specialists within 3 years of enactment. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to chapter 311 of title 49, United States Code. The Motor Carrier Safety Specialist Certification Act requires safety compliance reviews to be conducted by certified specialists within 3 years of enactment. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to chapter 311 of title 49, United States Code to certify motor carrier safety specialists. The Secretary of Transportation must establish a program within 12 months as required by section 31148(a) of title 49, United States Code. Within 24 months, at least 50% of Department of Transportation employees and all State and local government employees conducting compliance reviews must be certified under the program. Within 36 months, all Federal, State, and local employees, as well as non-governmental personnel, must be certified to conduct compliance reviews under the program established by the Secretary of Transportation as required by section 31148(a) of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 5. CLEARINGHOUSE FUNCTION. The Secretary of Transportation will accept and include information from non-governmental motor carrier safety specialists certified under section 31148, subject to verification by a designated clearinghouse. Data exchange protocols will be established by January 1, 2001 to process data received from these specialists. The Secretary of Transportation will ensure that information obtained from motor carrier safety specialists certified under section 31148 is made available to the public through a designated clearinghouse by January 1, 2002. The Secretary of Transportation will collaborate with the Motor Carrier Safety Specialist Certification Board to conduct a public education campaign promoting the use of safety performance information for hiring motor carriers. A Motor Carrier Safety Specialist is responsible for regulatory compliance reviews and safety inspections of commercial motor carriers.
